text: is Libya finally moving towards
stability
maybe but many here are watching and
waiting to see if the competing militias
and warring factions can be brought
under one roof a small crowd gathers in
tripolis martyrs square welcoming
Libya's new unity government it arrived
a few weeks ago backed by the UN the
problem is there are two governments
here already and there's another cause
for concern the so-called Islamic state
is now altering the equation here the
unity government warns the extremists
could take over most of the country the
Caribbean Libya does not have a strong
figure who can lead the army or even the
militias to fight this enemy he will
spurt quickly especially in the south
this area is weak and they could occupy
it in minutes if so they will control
two-thirds of the country when the West
started bombing the Libyan leaders
compound in Tripoli in 2011 things
weren't supposed to turn out like this
Britain and other nations involved have
been accused of not doing enough to
rebuild the country five years after
NATO intervened here against Colonel
Gaddafi this country is divided and
unstable and once again it's a growing
concern for the international community
there is a great deal at stake the
success or failure of the new unity
government has implications not just for
Libya but also for its neighbors and for
the West the scars of war remain here
but many want to look beyond the prism
of conflict
we visited Misrata during the revolution
with Gaddafi snipers still in residence
Abdul Hameed garish ah refused to leave
his home on the front lines two of his
neighbor's died for the new Libya thank
you
today he's still there ready to forgive
their killers and hoping the new
government can succeed we have to look
for the future forget all about war
comes violence enemies we have to live
in a peace we have to rebuild up Libya
Libya
back again that means the fragile new
government must secure streets where
militias call the shots there is a
growing sense that Libya needs help but
some in Britain may be gun-shy about
getting involved here again orna Gearin
BBC News Tripoli
